title: SuperM first K-Pop group to land Billboard number one debut album
text:
SuperM are number one (Picture: SM Entertainment, Capitol)

SuperM have made history by becoming the first K-Pop group to score a number one on the Billboard 200 chart with their debut album.

It’s amazing news for the ‘Avengers of K-Pop’ but some are questioning whether they would have achieved this without the bundle deals that were made available during the first week of release.

The boy group, consisting of Taemin from SHINee, Baekhyun and Kai from EXO, and Taeyong, Ten, Lucas and Mark from NCT, have claimed this week’s number one album in the US with their debut record, SuperM: The 1st Mini Album.

The seven-track record sold a total of 168,000 equivalent units in its first week of release. According to Billboard, 164,000 of those were from album sales and 4,000 came from streaming.

Breaking down the math, as 1,500 song streams are the equivalent to one sale, that means the album was streamed around 4.9 million times in just one week.

Oh, the power of streaming.

But the album release wasn’t as simple as it appears on the surface and it’s all down to those bundle deals that have become prevalent in the music industry to increase album sales.

SuperM released eight different versions, one for each member as well as a ‘united version’.

Digital copies of the album were included with every sale of merchandise on the SM Entertainment online store, including signed posters and picture disc vinyl.

They were also included with the purchase of tickets to SuperM’s US arena tour, which went on sale the day after the album release.

Pretty great timing.

But fans weren’t exactly kept in the dark about the bundle deals. In fact, SM Global Shop stated in their Instagram bio that ‘all orders officially count for the Billboard chart’.

R&B star Summer Walker, who currently holds the number two spot, also used similar sales tactics with her album Over It, by offering discounted merchandise and new t-shirts to fans during the first week of release.

It’s not the first time an artist has been scrutinised for reaching number one thanks to bundles.

Nicki Minaj called out Travis Scott in 2018 when his critically-acclaimed album Astroworld beat her own record, Queen, to number one after he sold albums with tour tickets and merchandise.

Nicki even accused the rapper of using his baby daughter Stormi to boost record sales.

And who can forget the controversy surrounding DJ Khaled back in June, when Billboard disqualified units that had been sold as part of a bundle with energy drinks?

At the moment, it seems to be a grey area but it looks like the charts are starting to accept bundle deals after all.
